Introduction

Imagine this: You open your email and see a message from a company you’ve never heard of offering you dog treats . You don’t have a dog. You don’t remember signing up. So… how did they get your info?

This is world of digital data. Every time we click “yes” without reading, sign up for something online, or use an app, we’re leaving little pieces of information about ourselves. Sometimes it’s harmless, but other times, it ends up in the hands of people we never intended to give it to.

That’s where the GDPR comes in.

 

What Is GDPR?

GDPR means General Data Protection Regulation.

It’s a law made by the European Union in 2016, and it became enforceable in May 2018.

Its purpose is to protect your personal data in the digital world and give you control over how it's used.

And here’s something important: GDPR doesn’t just apply to EU citizens. It protects anyone living in the EU, including:

  • migrants and refugees
  • people without citizenship
  • asylum seekers and students
  • using a service inside the EU

As long as you’re in the EU and a company, school, doctor, or platform collects your data, they must follow GDPR.

 

Why GDPR Matters – The 7 Rules of Data Protection

A quick look back: you move to a new city and go to register with the local health office. It’s 1997. The receptionist pulls out a giant folder with paper forms. Your name is written by hand, stored in a locked cabinet. Only one person handles it, and only when needed.

Now fast forward to today: you fill in a digital form on your phone. That information could be shared instantly with a government agency, a third-party service, a cloud server abroad, even an ad company. And just like that, your personal data starts travelling without a passport.

Before 2018, Europe had a data protection directive from 1995 - good for its time, but not made for smartphones, apps, or global data transfers. Companies were growing fast, often collecting and selling people’s information with little regulation. People didn’t know what was happening with their data and had no way to stop it.

The General Data Protection Regulation changed that. It gave people real control and forced organisations to follow clear rules. These rules are based on 7 key principles, like the “golden rules” of digital respect.

 

 

Why GDPR Matters – The 7 Rules of Data Protection

 


GDPR Principles
Lawfulness, Fairness & Transparency.
They must tell you clearly what they collect, why, and how.

You visit a job search website, and it asks you to create a profile. What you don’t see, unless you dig into the fine print, is that they also track your browsing and sell that data to marketing companies. Under GDPR, this is not allowed. The site must clearly inform you in simple language what data they collect and how they plan to use it.
Purpose Limitation.
They can only use your data for the reason they told you.		 If you gave your number to join a class, they can’t use it to send event ads later, unless you agreed.
Data Minimisation.
They should only ask for what they truly need.		 A website asking for your full ID and to subscribe to a newsletter is collecting too much.
Accuracy.
Your data should be kept correct and updated.		 You update your phone number in your online banking app, but they keep sending security codes to your old number. If your contact details aren’t updated correctly, you could be locked out—or worse, someone else could access your account.
Storage Limitation.
Data shouldn’t be kept forever.		 A job agency shouldn’t keep your CV for 10 years “just in case.”
Integrity and Confidentiality.
Your data must be protected from leaks or hacks.		 Health records must be stored with high security, not on an unprotected laptop.
Accountability.
The organisation must prove they follow all these rules.		 A company should be able to show they trained staff and secured their systems.

 

 

What Counts as Personal Data Anyway?

Think “personal data” is just your name and phone number? Think again. Your shopping habits, religion, even your face can count.

In today’s digital world, your personal data is more than just what you write on a form. Under the GDPR, personal data is defined as any information that relates to an identified or identifiable person.

That means anything that can be linked back to you - directly or indirectly.

Let’s start with the obvious:

Your name, address, phone number, email, or national ID number are clearly personal data. But GDPR goes further. Your IP address (the online "name tag" of your device), GPS location, photos of your face, social media activity, and even how you use apps can all be personal data, especially when combined with other information.

For example, if you’re using a health tracking app and it records your steps, sleep, and location, that’s all personal data. If the app knows your name or email, it can connect that data to you, which means it must follow GDPR rules.

This kind of information, like your steps, sleep patterns, and location, falls under what GDPR calls “special category data” because it relates to your health. Special category data is considered more sensitive and is given extra protection under the law. Companies are generally prohibited from processing this type of data unless they meet strict conditions, such as obtaining your explicit consent or having a clear legal basis, like for medical care or public health reasons. This means that if a health app wants to use your data, it must not only be transparent about what it collects and why, but it also needs to take extra steps to keep your information safe and respect your privacy at all times.

 

What Counts as Personal Data Anyway?

This includes sensitive information like:

  • Your ethnic or racial background

  • Your religious or political beliefs

  • Your health status

  • Your biometric data (like fingerprints or facial scans)

  • Your sexual orientation

  • Your immigration or asylum status

This kind of data is protected even more strictly under GDPR. Why? Because it could be used to discriminate, stigmatise, or harm people if misused.

So why do companies want all this data? Because it’s valuable. Your preferences, habits, and behavior help businesses target ads, sell products, or even make decisions about what content you see. In 2023, the digital advertising market in Europe was worth over €80 billion, and personal data is what fuels it.
That’s why understanding what counts as personal data is the first step in protecting yourself. If it can point to you, even indirectly – it’s personal. And thanks to GDPR, it’s protected.

 

 

Your GDPR Rights and How to Use Them

Another example: You notice your name is still listed on a public volunteer site you used years ago. You try to remove it, but there’s no delete button. You email the organization, and they say they’ll “look into it.” Under GDPR, you don’t have to just wait and hope. You have the legal right to demand that your data be deleted, and they must respond within 30 days. This final topic in the unit explains what GDPR rights you have, how they protect you, and how to use them in real life.

 

Gamification Activity 

[h5p id="6"]

 

In 2022, over 150,000 people across Europe exercised their rights under GDPR, asking questions, making complaints, and requesting erasures. You can do it too. Most organisations have a “Data Protection Officer” (DPO) you can contact. And if they ignore your request? You can contact your national Data Protection Authority, and they will investigate.

In short: GDPR puts you in the driver’s seat. Understanding your rights is the first step. Using them is the second.
